facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 970 of 1963 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 970 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the Award dated May 4, 196

facts.text: Appeal against award dated May 4, 1962 of the 2nd Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII146 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated May 4, 1962, -of the 2nd Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal, in Case No. VIII146 of 1961.

facts.text: Tribunal set aside dismissal of eleven workmen and ordered reinstatement with back wages except for January 2, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: by which the Tribunal set aside the dismissal of eleven workmen employed by the appellant Company and ordered their reinstatement with all back wages except wages for January 2, 1961.

facts.text: Appellant Company carries on activity as engineers and contractors in different parts of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company carries on activity as engineers and companytractors in different parts of West Bengal.

facts.text: Company had store yard at Sukchar employing 30 workmen, 11 permanent and remaining temporary.

anchor.surface_text: It had at Sukchar a store yard and at the relevant time it employed 30 workmen at Sukchar of whom 11 were permanent and the remaining temporary.

facts.text: Dismissal of the 11 permanent workmen from January 2, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with the dismissal of the permanent workmen from January 2, 1961.

facts.text: Company practice: fourteen days holidays each year including 1st January; if holiday on Sunday, following day holiday.

anchor.surface_text: According to the practice of the ,appellant Company fourteen days were holidays in each year. They included the 1st of January. Whenever a holiday fell on a Sunday the usual practice was to make the following day a holiday

facts.text: Dispute arose over 2nd January 1961 which followed a Sunday.

anchor.surface_text: and that is how the dispute arose over the 2nd of January which followed a Sunday in 1961.

facts.text: Eleven workmen did not attend work on 2nd January treating it as holiday (Union case).

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Union. in short, was that the eleven workmen did number attend work on 2nd of January treating it as a holiday

facts.text: Workmen expressly told Jan 2 working day due to pressure of work, holiday in lieu later (Company case).

anchor.surface_text: while the case of the appellant ,Company was that they had been expressly told that owing to pressure of work 2nd January was to be working day and a holiday in lieu would be given on another subsequent day.

facts.text: Absent workmen given charge-sheet, enquired, dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In view of their absence they were given a charge-sheet and after enquiry, were ordered to be dismissed.

facts.text: Workmen placed under suspension before enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Before the enquiry they were placed under suspension and at the instance of the Union a reference was made to the Labour Officer for companyciliation.

facts.text: Conciliation failed because appellant Company did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: The companyciliation failed because the appellant Company did number appear.

facts.text: Government of West Bengal referred to Labour Tribunal on April 21, 1961: whether dismissal of 11 workmen justified.

anchor.surface_text: A reference was made to the Labour Tribunal by the Government of West Bengal on April 21, 1961 of the following issue Whether the dismissal of the following workmen is justified what relief, if any, they are entitled to,  and  here followed the 11 names .

facts.text: Tribunal held no lock out or lay off, workmen went on strike but not illegal, dismissal victimization and unjustified.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its award held that there was numberlock out or lay off by the employer as was pleaded on behalf of the Union 1 1 Workmen had gone on a strike but it was number illegal and that the punishment of dismissal for this strike must be treated as victimization of the employees and was quite unjustified

facts.text: Enquiry Officer recommended dismissal of only 8 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that the Enquiry Officer recommended the dismissal of only 8 of these workmen.

facts.text: Quigly excused with warning and deprivation of wages for Jan 2 as he informed Works Manager.

anchor.surface_text: One Quigly, who was a Christian, was excused with a warning and deprivation of wages for 2nd January on the ground that he had informed the Works Manager that he would be unable to attend to his duties on 2nd January.

facts.text: J.C. Bose excused as joined on Dec 31, not knowing Jan 2 not holiday; warned, absence against leave.

anchor.surface_text: One J. C. Bose was excused because he had joined on the 31st December after absence and was number in a position to know that the 2nd January was number declared a holiday. He was also warned and his absence was adjusted against leave due to him.

facts.text: A.K. Sarkar on leave till Dec 31, informed by Quigly Jan 2 holiday; excused, warned, absence as leave.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, one A. K. Sarkar who was on leave till the 31st of December was excused because he was informed by Quigly that 2nd January would be a holiday. He was also warned and his absence was to be treated as leave with or without pay depending upon leave to his credit.

facts.text: Three workmen ordered to join duty but did not as Union said dispute pending for conciliation.

anchor.surface_text: These three persons were ordered to join duty but they did number as the Union was of the opinion that the original dispute was still pending for companyciliation and till the dispute was settled they companyld number join.

facts.text: Appellant contends reference bad as only 8 dismissed, not 11.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Company companytends that the reference is bad because it refers to 1 1 workmen as dismissed when only 8 were so treated.

facts.text: Court holds technically correct but no interference with award on this ground.

anchor.surface_text: Technically this is companyrect but we do number think that we should interfere with the award on this ground alone. All workmen were charged together and their defence more or less was that the day following the 1st of January was to be a holiday

facts.text: Tribunal found workmen went on strike, not illegal.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal was justified in interfering with the punishment of dismissal after it had companye to the companyclusion that the workmen had gone on a strike even though the strike was number illegal.

facts.text: Punishment of dismissal shockingly disproportionate; no reasonable employer would impose.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this is one of those cases in which it can plainly be said that the punishment imposed was one which numberreasonable employer would have imposed in like circumstances.

facts.text: Practice of substituting next day for holiday on Sunday done for number of years.

anchor.surface_text: There was a practice of substituting for a holiday falling on a Sunday, the clay next following. This appears to have been done in the appellant Company for a number of years.

holdings.text: the Tribunal can only interfere if the conduct of the employer shows lack of bona fides or victimization of employee or employees or unfair labour practice. The issue concerning justification of Tribunal's interference addresses the concept defining when Tribunal may interfere due to violation of natural justice in domestic enquiry.
Resolving whether Tribunal was justified in interfering requires application of the concept on natural justice principles in domestic enquiry.
Answering whether the Tribunal was justified in interfering requires the doctrine of interference with perverse findings.

The issue questions the Tribunal's interference with punishment for strike under management authority, which addresses the concept of Standing Orders governing punishment for misconduct unless unjust.
